Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Mechanisms of Mammalian Middle Ear Ossicle Transition from the Reptilian Jaw Joint
Award.AbstractNarration:
The transition from reptile to mammal was one of the most important events in leading to the eventual evolution of humans. This transition is characterized by many changes, one of the most important is the evolution of the mammalian middle ear. The goal of this project is to investigate the developmental basis of the evolution of the mammalian middle ear, using an opossum species as a model organism. Because opossum are primitive mammals, they can provide significant insights into mammalian evolution, and the improved understanding of ear development that this project will generate has the potential to positively impact human health. This project will also serve as a foundation for the STEM training of several undergraduates and for community outreach events geared toward K-12 students. Results of this project are also being incorporated into a three-part PBS documentary based upon Neil Shubin's best-selling book, Your Inner Fish.

The reptilian jaw consists of multiple bones, while there is only a single bone in the reptile middle ear. Conversely, the mammalian jaw consists of a single bone, while there are multiple bones in the mammal middle ear. It has been shown, via paleontology and embryology, that the extra bones in the mammalian middle ear originated from the extra bones in the reptilian jaw. Separation from the jaw would allow more flexibility in the evolution of the middle ear elements, resulting in increased hearing sensitivity and amplified frequency range. The middle ear changes observed in the transition from reptiles to mammals in the fossil record also occur during development in opossum. Opossum are born with a middle ear similar to reptiles, but in adults the middle ear is mammalian, providing a unique opportunity to study the evolutionary development of mammalian middle ear bones in an currently living organism rather than with fossils. The project is based on a detailed characterization of the transition using micro-computed tomography scans to create three-dimensional images at five day intervals, beginning at birth, and studying the cellular processes underlying the transition by cryosectioning at the noted stages, followed by immunohistochemistry for cell proliferation and apoptosis. The project will uncover the genes responsible for the transition using in situ hybridization and RNA sequencing. Alterations in the timing of expression and concentration of particular genes (e.g., TGTbr2 and Eya1) are expected to be correlated with the separation of Meckel's cartilage and functional changes in the ossicles. The research will determine if the active genes in opossum are also expressed in the middle ear region of placental mammals. The project will compare the transition that occurs during opossum development to that observed in fossil record leading to early mammal lineages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to study the development of a modern marsupial for the purposes of better understanding the processes that drove significant physical changes along the evolutionary transition from reptiles to mammals. Specifically, we sought to characterize the transition of elements that began in the reptile jaw and later became incorporated into the mammalian middle ear, as well as, the mechanisms responsible for this change. Our study organism, Monodelphis domestica, is a small marsupial that recapitulates the sequence of changes observed in the fossil record during their early postnatal development. Using micro-CT scans we demonstrated the close relationship between Monodelphis developmental changes and those observed in well preserved early mammalian fossils.

 

We then focused on the cellular processes that were responsible for separating the middle ear elements from the jaw via breakdown of the Meckel’s cartilage. We have found a form of cellular death, apoptosis, causes the degradation of this element. Interestingly, this method is different from what takes place in placental mammals, such as humans. Funding from this doctoral dissertation improvement grant allowed us to sequence the RNA from Meckel’s cartilage at different time points to determine which genes were responsible for the onset of breakdown and ultimately separation of the middle ear from the jaw. During the period of Meckel’s degradation we found significant upregulation of several important genes associated with apoptosis and cartilage resorption. Despite the difference in cellular mechanisms between marsupials and placentals, we found a key gene (Tgfbr2) operating at this point in both sets of organisms. By inhibiting gene expression of Tgfbr2 prior to the onset of Meckel’s resorption we have been able to prolong the connection between the middle ear and the jaw beyond the point that it would normally breakdown.

 

The separation of middle ear elements from the jaw is observed in multiple independent lineages of early mammals. While these fossils are much too old for us to determine the genes that were once active in the living organisms, we can use modern animals to serve as a proxy for our understanding. The similarity of Tgfbr2 gene expression in very distantly separated mammalian lineages implies that it may have played a significant role in the development of their ancestors as well. The separation of middle ear elements from the jaw represents a profound evolutionary shift that would initially seem unlikely to happen multiple times. However, finding that changes in expression level of just one or a few genes is sufficient to prolong or initiate this separation in modern organisms helps explain the seeming ease with which this transition has repeatedly occurred.

 

Our findings help elucidate a significant evolutionary change occurring along the origin of mammals that continues to be an important facet of our own development. We have been able to gain insights into the mechanisms driving this evolutionary change and the gene functions that help regulate our own mammalian development. Throughout the course of this work, several undergraduate and graduate students have learned a variety of new techniques to aid in their own burgeoning scientific inquiries. In addition, insights from this work have been presented at numerous scientific conferences and K-12 outreach events, as well as, broadcast nationally in the Emmy award-winning documentary “Your Inner Fish.”
